messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:06): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: i can't find a step 2 that says to go to step 2, and the two step algorithm does have two steps. (well 7, if you include the 5 inner steps of step 1)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:10): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: It's "1. If position points to: <stuff with two "a sequence" things, the second with 5 steps>  2. Otherwise, return to step 2 in these inner steps."

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:11): and then it has "A sequence of bytes starting with a 0x3C byte (ASCII '<'), optionally a 0x2F byte (ASCII '/'), and finally a byte in the range 0x41-0x5A or 0x61-0x7A (an ASCII letter)" outside the list it should probably be in (introduced by "If position points to:")
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:12): uh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:12): yes clearly that step 2 is wrong
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:12): perhaps because the "case-insensitive ASCII '&lt;meta' followed by a space or slash" bit has an <ol> with a <p> child
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:12): oh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:12): i see
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:12): massive markup error
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:12): will gix
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:12): fix
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:14): not catched by the validator?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:14): the preprocessor "fixed" it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:15): ah yeah, that happens
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:15): maybe run it over the source?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:15): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Oh, good idea
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:15): well, you need to prefix the source with something first I guess
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:16): I assume it'd recover after complaining it was missing the doctype and title
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:16): ok i should have fixed that list issue
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:16): looks now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:16): i'll fix the rest later
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:17): so just ignore the first four messages and fix the next near-infinite errors
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:17): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Okay, thanks!

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:19): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: you output three messages when one end tag has been substituted for another
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:19): as in, <span>...</code>...</p>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:20): missing </span>, unexpected </code>, and <span> still open at </p>.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:40): in fact the >1000 errors are only at most 50 or so
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:40): all fixed now

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:46): (there is, just not sure how to get it)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:47): cool thanks
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:47): &out=text

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:47): well maybe out=text is ok
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:49): for out=gnu you could simply check if the amount of lines is greater than 4
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:49): out=text uses wacky ass quotation marks
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:50): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: ?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:50): if the return value has more than 4 lines you have hit a regression
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:50): and need to fix your markup
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:50): nope. out=text still uses silly quotation marks
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:50): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: any chance i can get a US-ASCII output mode? :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:51): heh, the validator caught my en-GB-hixie error
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:51): guess i'd better fix it

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:53): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I'm talking about out=gnu, it uses those quotation marks too, but i'm not sure why that's relevant if you simply want to catch regressions
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:54): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: out=gnu is an UTF-8 output mode. (It'll change a bit soon as the GNU spec is amended.) UTF-8 is the new US-ASCII. ;-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:55): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: out=text is for human reading. you shouldn't try to write a program to parse it.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:55): accidentally outputs the w3c version to the whatwg site
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:56): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: yeah i was just confused about why you wanted to skip 4 lines? shouldn't i want zero errors?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:57): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: how seriously do you need a US-ASCII mode and what should it do with non-ASCII characters?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:57): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, oh, I was assuming you wouldn't prefix the source file with the WHATWG header file

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:57): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: i don't want to parse it. i have my emacs configured to US-ASCII with any 8 bit bytes displayed in octal, so that i can easily edit test cases with malformed byte sequences
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:57): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: so your quotation marks look like \123\123\123
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:57): really it's just a "no fancy quotes" mode that i'd like :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:58): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: in my script it's already done, so that's not a problem
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:59): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: out=gnu is meant to be emacs-friendly, but only when emacs is configured to do UTF-8
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:00): specifically i get:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:00): http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/source-whatwg:1.51-2.25: error: Bad value \342\200\234en-GB-hixie\342\200\\
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:00): 235 for attribute \342\200\234lang\342\200\235 on element \342\200\234html\342\200\235: Bad variant subtag.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:00): i guess it's not a big deal, just looks ugly and makes it hard to work out what the error is
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: can you give me a spec for some processing magic before the UTF-16 to UTF-8 conversion?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: just replacing the quotes?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:02): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: out of curiosity, what code do you use for integrating emacs and the Web service?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:06): curl
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:06): and yeah, just replacing quotes with " would solve my immediate problem

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:13): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: it's http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=135 now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:14): do the fancy quotes provide any direct benefit to users?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:14): apart from looking arguably prettier in certain contexts?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:15): because frankly they also cause me other problems, like i can't easily copy and paste them across ssh sessions
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:15): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: they disambiguate start and end better and they don't themselves occur in XML/HTML syntax
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:16): fair enough

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:48): hmm, should I fix IFRAME drawing inside SVG filters on Mac, just so I can adapt reftest-analyzer to work with live testcases?
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:02): ah, he's talking about FF SVG
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (23:03): 6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8: With that kind of enthusiasm, who cares about the tangentialness of the relevance ;)
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:05): would like someone to fix rightsizing in webkit
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (23:06): oops wrong channel
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (23:07): but it *is* kind of cool that with SVG filters, IFRAMEs and foreignobject you can create a pixel-level page comparison tool in a Web app
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:07): rightsizing?!
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:07): was hoping that terminology would not be used outside the CDF WG
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (23:08): oh, have they got a spec for that?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (23:08): wonders what rightsizing is if it's not a euphemism for sacking everyone
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:08): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: we need a term for those bugs
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (23:09): I think it means "give IFRAMEs a meaningful intrinsic size" (or height at least)
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:09): so I stole the CDF WG's term
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:09): oh, no that's another set of bugs 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:09): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: that's just implementing CSS 2.1 :)
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:10): CSS 2.1 requires inline replaced elements to support relative intrinsic sizes
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:10): which we in webkit at least don't support
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (23:10): you mean the aspect-ratio-preserving stuff?
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:10): so things like <object> don't corretly pick up the height="100%" off of their svg child doc
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:10): I don't think current browsers ever give <iframe> a useful intrinsic size
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:10): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: the aspect-ratio-preserving stuff is "right sizing"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:10): even if you put a fixed-size raster image in it
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:11): so it's not really the same issue as <object?
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (23:11): CSS2.1 specifies that IFRAME intrinsic sizes should depend on the child document? news to me
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:11): 6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8, aspect ratio is also CSS 2.1
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:11): (it would be handy if <iframme> could size appropriately to a child HTML document, but you'd need some way to ask for that in CSS)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:11): 6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8, in fact, if it's not, rightsizing would be a violation of CSS 2.1, which is not what you want...
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (23:12): yeah, that's what I want (and the Web needs I think)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:12): (having said that, CSS 2.1 should just say whatever is most fancy and works)
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (23:12): I actually had a patch for it in Gecko, but there's a concern about information leakage
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (23:12): for cross-domain frames
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:13): rightsizing entered into my lingo from the WICD tests http://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=15836... I might be using it wrong though
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:13): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: this is the CSS 2.1 bug of which I speak: http://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=15849
6923fbf94c13b38a31f434d910ffbef8 (23:13): which causes us to fail hixie's tests: http://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=15473
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:26): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: with <http://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17023> you better paste it all again with the changes :P
